none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. C. Caldwell, December 19, 1886
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. C. Caldwell, December 19, 1886
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 23 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
Corpus Christi, Texas,
Dec 19th 1886

Prof. L. L. McInnis
A. & M. College

Dear Sir and friend: Your favor of
the first inst reached me, in the due course of
time - I was then absent on a Surveying tour -

After graduating in '83, I spent one winter with
My Uncle in Dallas; returning home I at once
embarked in my old business - Land Surveying -
Since then I have had many ups and downs, chiefly
in favor of the downs, unfortunately for myself; but I
guess there is no cloud without a silver lining -

Last June I secured a good position on the
S. A. and A. P. R. R. which lasted until the road was
completed to this place - last November -; during this
period I superintended the Reef bridge, 1 3/4 m. in length,
and 3. m of R.R. track. I also brushed up on my
Trigonometry and Civil Engineering to a considerable extent,
I believe I can now handle a transit or level, and
make all the adjustments better than any one of
the same experience as myself.

Thanking you for your kind letter
of recommendation, and wishing you health, happiness
and success, I remain
Yours Ever Sincerely
J. C. Caldwell

P.S. I now hold the position of City Engineer of
Corpus Christi, and Surveyor of Duval County.

**Analysis and Transcription of a Handwritten Letter**

Alright, let's break this down. First, I'm looking at the overall format: handwritten letter on lined paper. The crucial details jump out immediately. Top right, we have "Corpus Christi, Texas, Dec 19th 1886," pinpointing the origin and date. Top left, the recipient is clearly "Prof. L. L. McInnis A. & M. College". The salutation is respectful, "Dear Sir and friend:".

Now, for the body... it's all about extracting the words correctly while keeping the original layout. "Your favor of the first inst reached me..." sets the tone. I'll need to keep the line breaks accurate throughout this process. "After graduating in '83, I spent one winter..." Okay, there's a little ambiguity on the number of winters spent. I'm going with 'one' after careful scrutiny. It's a key detail to capture.

The letter dives into his work experience.  "...Land Surveying...",  "...ups and downs...", a silver lining is mentioned. He got a position on the "S. A. and A. P. R. R.", then there's the "Reef bridge, 1 3/4 m. in length". I want to make sure I include the "3. m of R.R. track". "Trigonometry and Civil Engineering..." Ah, he's keeping sharp. He believes he can "...handle a transit or level, and make all the adjustments...". It's a nice note of confidence, followed by a formal closing.

The closing is standard, "Yours Ever Sincerely, J. C. Caldwell". Then there's the P.S.: He's now "City Engineer of Corpus Christi, and Surveyor of Duval County." That's the most recent piece of information.

To make this completely accurate, I'm going to transcribe line by line, preserving the letter's structure and any nuances. Let's make sure the "th" in "19th" is superscript, and preserve the capitalization. And remember to keep the line breaks! The formatting needs to be preserved. Let's make sure that's correct, then I'll finalize the transcription.
